(Széchenyi István Memorial Exhibition [[Nagycenk]])]] '''Ottó Titusz Bláthy''' (Tata 11 August 1860 – Budapest 26 September 1939) was a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] [[electrical engineer]]. In his career, he became the co-inventor of the modern electric [[transformer]],<ref>Encyclopaedia Britannica</ref> the [[tension regulator]],<ref name="IPC">{{cite web|url=http://profiles.incredible-people.com/otto-titusz-blathy/ | title=Biography of Otto Titusz Blathy | work = Incredible People | accessdate=2010-09-28}}</ref> ([[Voltage stabilizer]]), the AC [[electricity meter|watt-hour meter]],<ref name="IPC"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Eugenii Katz |url=http://people.clarkson.edu/~ekatz/scientists/blathy.html |title=Blathy |publisher=People.clarkson.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-08-04| archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080625015707/http://people.clarkson.edu/~ekatz/scientists/blathy.html| archivedate = June 25, 2008}}</ref> [[Motor capacitor]] for the single-phase (AC) electric motors, the [[turbo generator]], and the high efficiency turbo generator. Ottó Titusz's career as an inventor began during his time at the [[Ganz]] Works in 1883. It is noteworthy, that the name "transformer" was created by Ottó Titusz Bláthy.<ref>http://energyhistory.energosolar.com/en_19th_century_electric_history.htm</ref> There, he conducted experiments for creating a transformer. In 1885 the ''ZBD'' model alternating-current transformer was invented by three Hungarian engineers: Ottó Bláthy, [[Miksa Déri]] and [[Károly Zipernowsky]]. (''ZBD'' comes from the initials of their names). In the autumn of 1889 he patented the [[AC Watt meter]].<ref>Ricks, G.W.D. This paper appears in: Electrical Engineers, Journal of the Institution of Issue Date: March 1896 Volume: 25 Issue: 120 On page(s): 57 - 77 Digital Object Identifier: 10.1049/jiee-1.1896.0005</ref> [[Image:Blathy wattmeter.jpg|thumb|220px|Bláthy's Wattmeter]] Besides his scientific work, Ottó Titusz Bláthy is well known as an author of [[chess problem]]s. He specialized in the field of very long [[moremovers]], also known as longmovers.
